item.description:
XSLT Extensions for JSON Processing Michael Kay #balisage2022

MK: Talk = Mix of ideas wrt JSON in XSLT; some cooked, some more half-baked #balisage2022

MK: What's in XSLT 3.0? Some JSON-specific things (parse/serialize/convert functions), some applicable to data model behind JSON (maps and arrays, various functions, esp. maps) #balisage2020

#balisage2022 Mary timetravels again

MK: Prague paper 2016 looked at JSON transformation and best way was JSON => XML => JSON Which is... disappointing Can we do better? Transform natively? #balisage2022

MK: Consider two use cases

  1. Leave everything except change one thing
  2. Hierarchical inversion #balisage2022

MK: Issues No array constructor Map construction not aligned with map deconstruction No ancestor access in JSON tree Poor support types/patterns matching maps/arrays (JSON maps don't have names) No suitable built-in template rules #balisage2022

MK: (Shows solutions to two use cases, using various proposed mechanisms, to be looked at in a bit) #balisage2022

MK: Record types New way of describing maps, both ItemType and Pattern List keys in map, can put * at end to make extensible, can make keys optional, can provide types, keys have to be strings but don't have to be NCNames, can define as recursive w/ 'as ..' #balisage2022

MK: Constructing/deconstructing maps and arrays Existing languages is sequence-focused, so want ways of decomposing array/map into sequence of pieces, and then reassemble map pieces are entries (key-value pairs) array pieces are parcels= item wraps sequence #balisage2022

MK: via() function to give access to apply-templates stack (replacement for ancestor) #balisage2022

item.description:
Human Readability of Data Files Michael Robert Gryk

#balisage2022

MG: Recap of STAR format Thinking now about human readability: how do we define that? #balisage2022

MG: Shows various examples of formats called "human readable" sans definitions #balisage2022

MG: Look at readability in the context of human texts, e.g.Flesch metric based on average sentent length, number of affixes, number of references to people #balisage2022

MG: Developed to "reading ease" based on average words per sentence, average syllables per word #balisage2022

MG: Take this idea and apply to data formats? How? Analogy to sentences, words, syllables? #balisage2022

MG: In STAR: names/identifiers, data values, comments, syntactical constructs What to count? Identifiers: more is better? #balisage2022

MG: For syntax elements, seems less is better #balisage2022

MG: characters in data names + value divided by total characters (minus whitespace and comments) #balisage2022

MG: Tricky areas comments, white space #balisage2022

MG: Issues/pain points Comments: ignore because JSON has no comments, so made it not comparable Commented-out code wrt readability? #balisage2022

item.description:
Migrating DocBook to Uncharted Waters Ari Nordström, Jean Kaplansky

#balisage2022

JK: The quest Migrate 50GB of MathML heavy DocBook, update, normalize, move to LMS, ...

on a short time frame

#balisage2022

JK: XIncludes, weird Arbortext PIs, MathML, entities upon top of entities

#balisage2022

[A case study in technological archaeology]

JK: Problem finding someone to help take on this quest

Eventually got to Ari

#balisage2022

AN: "This should be easy" DocBook 4.0 => 4.3 => XHTML "Pipelines!"

#balisage2022

AN: Let's talk about clean up

Normalize Tweak Encode (=>UTF8)

#balisage2022

AN: Normalization Pull in XInclude links, add targets to xproc filter to skip the included links Easy, right?

Um... source has its own file protocol URIs With lots of extra characters

So... file renaming step which also needs to fix the refs #balisage2022

AN: Encoding Just serialize XML in UTF-8

Uh: XIncluded bits included decades of character entities, but with DOCTYPEs that defined them commented out and the commented out things had wrong names...

So: Use TagSoup to add in right DOCTYPEs

#balisage2022

AN: New issues with those fragments where things depended on context, so needed more complicated plan

#balisage2022

AN: Complications on top of complications

[Isn't it ever thus? Everything is always more complicated than you can possibly imagine.]

#balisage2022

AN: Ended up doing a lot of pre-conversion as part of fix-ups, ended up with a lot of keep=true to keep DocBook stylesheets from messing with them in weird ways

#balisage2022

AN: "There were namespace issues"

#balisage2022

[Evergreen tweet]

AN: In hindsight I should have done this in XProc 3.0

#balisage2022

JK: We learned a LOT more than we ever thought:

Identify ALL stakeholders at start w DIRECT rep participating in project

Project teams might have own ideas of XML best practices, etc.

Ensure stakeholder has resources + training

...

#balisage2022

JK: (Lessons, cont)

Stakeholders may change priorities in middle, a lot

Define preferred format for client feedback from the start

Set expectations FIRMLY from the start

Set legal/financial aspects BEFORE starting work

#balisage2022

item.description:
Designing for Change: Pragmas as an Extensibility Mechanism for Invisible XML Tomos Hillman, C. M. Sperberg-McQueen, Bethan Tovey-Walsh, Norm Tovey-Walsh #balisage2022

BTW: Two precepts

  1. There are rules for a reason
  2. Question authority

#balisage2022

BTW: Want a way to break the rules without imposing our mistakes on the world, a way to innovate but still maintain the standard

#balisage2022

Pragmas: give instructions to processor, generally out of scope of language semantics

#balisage2022

BTW: Our proposal for iXML pragmas is NOT official at this point

Pragmas will be ignored by pragma-unaware processors; will be understood by processor that understands that particular pragma

#balisage2022

NTW: Example Pragma is specially structured comment {[pragma]} vs {normal comment}

#balisage2022

NTW: Naming Special reserved pragma: {[+pragma myPragma "https://t.co/C6tzMGlzma"]} sets the name to namespace association

#balisage2022

NTW: Various examples: renaming, make this a token, resolving ambiguity

#balisage2022

NTW: Experimental pragma that became part of the language: insertions One goal is to provide mechanism to experiment with things to see how they work #balisage2022

NTW: Several implementors are working on this; mine implements several. Next step is to turn paper into spec #balisage2022

Q: iXML spec has several extra-grammatical constraints Would these be good candidates for pragmatization? A: Yes, possibly, not sure of details #balisage2022

Q: Fan of extensibility, but worried about interoperability. By definition not interoperable. Don't see advantage of adding this to language. A: There are things that shouldn't be part of language, e.g. ambiguity. Things making sense to particular processors... #balisage2022

... Also, if there need to be ways to communicate things to processor, better to have one way than multiple ways. Believe there are those cases,there are limits to what iXML can express and may WANT different behaviours [[a debate that will continue; good points on both sides]]

MSM A: Why not bring use cases not pragma? Because most such proposals cannot be implemented. Having a proof-of-implementation short-circuits those debates.

#balisage2022

MSM continues: analogy with Private Use areas in Unicode

#balisage2022

JL: Another use, for annotating grammar for when you project it into a different kind of grammar. That's what I've been using it for. A: I have notion of using annotation to add DC metadata to grammar #balisage2022

item.description:
BITS for Government Information? Ravit H. David #balisage2022

RD: Scholars Portal E-books Service Recent redesign: what metadata standard to use? #balisage2022

RD: Load information from various publishers, various formats, various XML vocabularies, various metadata

#balisage2022

RD: BITS=book interchange tags format (cousin to JATS)

#balisage2022

RD: BITS is focused on scientific/technical books Government information is a bit of a stretch

#balisage2022

RD: For government information in mixed archive, need book type info plus second level information of subtype

#balisage2022

RD: Gov vs corporate author: richer information about source author/orgnanization/ministry/department publisher="Queen's Printer" is not very informative various contributors and collaborators in play "in cooperation with", "prepared by", etc.

#balisage2022

RD: More complexity: different metadata associated with different parts of the digitization process and wrt the print version of the report Important to be able to record this Also want to know creator/provenance of metadata too #balisage2022

item.description:
Serverless Searching with XSLT and JavaScript Joey Takeda, Martin Holmes #balisage2022

JT: The Endings project: collaboration to figure out how to ensure long-term survival of projects #balisage2022

JT: Most sustainable, archivable: static websites (HTML, CSS, JavaScript, minimal dependencies) #balisage2022

JT: Problem: How to add search to static websites? #balisage2022

JT: Client side libraries? Have to be in memory; doesn't scale to large websites. Google? elasticsearch? Other issues. Decided to build our own: staticSearch, client side website search #balisage2022

JT: staticSearch XSLT/Ant process to generated inverted index of JSON files

Has stemming in multiple languages, wildcards, exact phrases, boolean, configurable filters, contextual...

Every search is bookmarkable URL

#balisage2022

JT: Input: collection of WF HTML5 in XHTML namespace Plus: configuration file #balisage2022

JT: rules tell you what to exclude (default is index everything), contexts to give labels (use match patterns) #balisage2022

JT: Stemming using own implementation of Porter2 plus "diacritic" stemmer and "identity" stemmer, can also use your own (XSLT + JavaScript); in config #balisage2022

JT: Create "inverted index" JSON files, per stem gets instances; fetched one by one by JavaScript in search #balisage2022

JT: Create other additional information during indexing: list of titles, list of all (unstemmed) words (used for wildcarding via regex) #ballisage2022

JT: Filters and controls generated during indexing; can be used to build the search page #balisage2022

JT: Considerations Limiting factor is titles (e.g. 170K pages project => 15MB titles file) No easy way to show matches in document Context-specific searches, no conditional logic for filters #balisage2022

JT: Solution for context-specific search is separate search pages over different parts (plus more generic for whole site) #balisage2022

JT: Lots of stem files feels wrong, but seems to work OK #balisage2022

JT: Create other additional information during indexing: list of titles, list of all (unstemmed) words (used for wildcarding via regex) #ballisage2022
JT: Filters and controls generated during indexing; can be used to build the search page #balisage2022
JT: Considerations Limiting factor is titles (e.g. 170K pages project => 15MB titles file) No easy way to show matches in document Context-specific searches, no conditional logic for filters #balisage2022
JT: Solution for context-specific search is separate search pages over different parts (plus more generic for whole site) #balisage2022
JT: Lots of stem files feels wrong, but seems to work OK #balisage2022

Invisible XML Coming into Focus Tomos Hillman; John Lumley; Steven Pemberton; C. M. Sperberg-McQueen; Bethan Tovey-Walsh; Norm Tovey-Walsh #balisage2022

BTW: iXML 1.0 What's it for? "What if you could see everything as XML?" Recognizing abstractions: these things are "the same" #balisage2022

BTW: But also need to understand abstractions in context, which changes their interpretation Abstractions in context = seeing things as XML Make this visible to the computer #balisage2022

BTW: How does iXML work? iXML grammar => parse input stream => XML #balisage2022

BTW: What's new? Spec: iXML 1.0 Community group Processor behaviour defined Infrastructure: tests, sample grammars, implementations #balisage2022

MSM: Speaking of Aparecium implementation Implemented in XQuery Trying to make loading non-XML resources as easy as loading them as text or XML as XML (Demo) #balisage2022

MSM: Biggest issue right now: too slow for production use #balisage2022

SB: ixampl implementation Originally built as test bed for language concepts; designed to be flexible rather than fast Has a bootstrap parser Web app or command line, written in ABC #balisage2022

JL: jwiXML implementation JavaScript library + SaxonJS/XSLT API to run in browser Browser-based interactive workbench (Demo) #balisage2022

JL: Demo of XPath grammar minimization to get nice tree without all kinds of deep extraneous junk #balisage2022

Love it!

NTW: NineML implementation Java based implementation Can also produce JSON (Demo) #balisage2022

NTW: Or CSV Or SVG diagram of parse #balisage2022

NTW: Recently added GLL parser which is sometimes slower than Earley parser and sometimes much much faster #balisage2022

SB: What's next? Extend infrastructure Encourage new iXML projects Engage with iXML users Evolve next iXML version: look for use cases and figure how to integrate that in language

Welcome to join group, sign up at W3C

#balisage2022

item.description:
Correcting Collation Problems with XSLT Elisa E. Beshero-Bondar

#balisage2022

EBB: Machine-assisted collation; here the various publications of Mary Shelley's Frankenstein #balisage2022

EBB: Gothenburg model of computer-aided collation

  1. Tokenization (Smallest unit of comparison)
  2. Normalization (e.g. & = and)
  3. Alignment (chunking, identifiable start/end pts)]
  4. Analysis
  5. Visualization Iterate #balisage2022

EBB: Metaphor: collation as weaving #balisage2022

EBB: Tokenization; we need to be able to intervene in tokenization and normalization as part of our scholarship #balisage2022

EBB: When to make interventions? Pre- vs Post-? Pre-processing better, but can go overboard and make new problems Post-processing with XSLT? Yes, with care #balisage2022

EBB: Tokenization and alignment is a research method More than one way to do it So scholars/programmers: share your algorithms #balisage2022

EBB: Error correction is cyclical and hard Need to document errors and interventions #balisage2022

EBB: Machine-assisted processes need a lot of documentation #balisage2022

Excuse for shout-out to my talk later in the week (Metadata for Creators), which is all about instrumentation of processes subject to a lot of cyclical tweakage #balisage2022

Really really like this metaphor and how she applied it Wish I could have better captured it from the EBB firehose of information
